question.text: The ionization energies of <math> <mrow> <mtext>Li</mtext></mrow> </math> and <math> <mrow> <mtext>Na</mtext></mrow> </math> are <math> <mrow> <mtext>520</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>kJ</mtext></mrow> </math> <math><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> and <math> <mrow> <mtext>495</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>kJ</mtext><mtext> </mtext><msup> <mrow> <mtext>mol</mtext></mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow> </msup> </mrow> </math> respectively. The energy required to convert all the atoms present in <math> <mrow> <mtext>7</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>mg</mtext></mrow> </math> of <math> <mrow> <mtext>Li</mtext></mrow> </math> vapours and <math> <mrow> <mtext>23</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>mg</mtext></mrow> </math> of sodium vapours to their respective gaseous cations respectively are:

solution.text:
For 1 mole Li i.e. 7 g will absorb 520 kJ heat
So for 7 mg lithium heat absorbed will be 520 J
Similarly for sodium
1 mole Na i.e. 23 g will absorb 495 kJ Heat
So for 23 mg sodium heat absorbed will be 520 J
